TopicTitle: What software do you guys use to make textures?

Articles.Content: I've been working on a couple projects, but I can't seem to texture them well using GIMP. When you make your mods, what software do you use to texture them?
I use Photoshop. I believe CS2 is free these days.
Photoshop. Layers are your friend!
Photoshop. I pay the $19/month for CC

Old photoshop is pretty sufficient for texturing. 

I also use Paint .NET and GIMP.
Krita, Gimp and PS.

> 
> I use Photoshop. I believe CS2 is free these days.

It has pretty much all the useful features too ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

I use both Adobe Fireworks CS6 for most of my textures, and Adobe Photoshop CS6 for normal maps.

**[MOD - Also, moved to Modelling and Texturing Discussion subforums]**
Photoshop CS5 here.
Photoshop CS6 here.

Go hardcore. Use zbrush:sticktongue:

in all fairness i use mostly use photoshop + filters for general texturing but the projection master in zb has a lot of nice texturing features. Combine it with a bit of surface sculpting you really got something.

GIMP + Blender bakes (shadow/light, AO, Norm, baking procedural textures onto a UV texture map occasionally). I totally forgot that I had the old free PS laying around, or I might have started learning and using that; but GIMP seems to do everything I need. Maybe someday I'll look into some of the real/professional tools to see what all the excitement is about ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

Photoshop CS 2014 and a wacom digital tablet. I also use Modo for doing ambient occlusion and diffuse geometry bakes. Actually, I'm planning to releasing a video tutorial all about my texture making process soon-ish.
Paint.net. :S And GIMP (2) for normal maps.

Some ppl also use mudbox for texture painting directly on your 3dmodel(projection painting).

I havent really tried it but its similar to the same feature available in blender and zbrush(projection master). 

The advantage as i see it over flat texturing in ps/gimp is that you see the result as you paint. This is very useful for painting extra scratches etc. Tho some things like adding geometric shapes edge effects and patterns are much better done i ps/gimp imo.

Ofcource if you are just texturing other ppls models then ps/gimp might be the only thing you need.

As said texture baking(color/ao/normals/cavity from highpoly or directly from your lowpoly) is also very valuable in the texturing process but not required

I use Photoshop CS3, GIMP to convert my bump maps to normal maps, and GraphiConverter 9 to convert my textures to DDS.

> 
> I use Photoshop CS3, GIMP to convert my bump maps to normal maps, and GraphiConverter 9 to convert my textures to DDS.

You do know you can use GIMP also to convert DDS.

I've been using Photoshop until I met 3D Coat.

3D Coat is AWESOME. I still use Photoshop for some things, the cool thing is that 3D Coat has an exporting feature to Photoshop and it updates once saved.

**Photoshop** + [**Quixel Suite**](http://quixel.se/) here. Quixel is especially cool, because you can import a 3D model and see all changes you make in real time. And it has a very nice collection of premade materials. For normals I use Blender baking and Quixel nDO. NVIDIA Photoshop plug-ins enable Photoshop to open edit and save .DDS files directly.

They are currently building the Megascans library, some of the materials are already included with dDO.

> 
> I've been working on a couple projects, but I can't seem to texture them well using GIMP. When you make your mods, what software do you use to texture them?

There's a GIMP plug-in to handle DDS files, but I do most of my texture work in Paint Shop Pro and then use GIMP as a converter. PSP does have layers and that is a useful tool, but if I were starting from scratch , no experience, I'd be inclined to concentrate on GIMP. I am constrained by my history.
